abstracts.cdata!:
The outcome of the project is
            satisfactory, and sustainability is likely. Among the
            several lessons learned, it is suggested that an emerging
            financial sector requires, not only the reform policy, and
            legislature supporting same, but special attention on
            strengthening public awareness about these reforms. The
            Government's commitment to such reforms, which conveyed
            a strong ownership, played a paramount role for the success
            of the project, along with the interplay between technical
            assistance, and adjustment lending, which provided the
            continuity to sustain the momentum of the reform process.
            But a gradual approach to reform, requires that all parties
            remain abreast of each change, regardless of their impact,
            to be able to move forward in the transition period. The
            continued financial support for institutional capacity
            building is a long-term commitment, which should be
            strengthened within the supervisory agencies, and, allow for
            a decrease of dependence on multilateral aid. The total
            closure of old pension systems, when starting new pension
            systems, conveys a strong commitment to the performance of
            reform, thus its reform process is simplified, and the
            compliance cost for enterprises is reduced, becoming
            equitable among all sectors of the working population.
